title: A Phase I, Single Center, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Single Ascending Dose, Pharmacokinetic and Safety Study of PTl-125 in Healthy Volunteers
description_brief: A Phase I, Single Center, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Single Ascending Dose, Pharmacokinetic and Safety Study of PTl-125 in Healthy Volunteers
description_detailed:
This was a Phase I, single center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, single ascending dose (SAD) study in healthy volunteers, 18 to 45 years of age. A total of twenty-four (24) subjects were enrolled into the study in one of three dose cohorts. Each cohort contained eight subjects; six subjects received PTI-125 and two received placebo. Three doses of PTI-125 oral solution (50, 100, and 200 mg) or placebo solution were administered to respective cohorts.

The study included a screening period (Day -28 to Day -1), an inpatient treatment period (Day 0 through Day 4), and a follow-up visit (Day 7). Subjects reported to the clinic on the day before dosing and were randomized to receive either a single dose of orally administered PTI-125 or placebo. Each dose was administered following an overnight fast of at least 10 hours.

For each dose level, dosing was staggered such that two subjects (one active and one placebo) were dosed prior to the rest of the group. After a minimum of 24 hours and review of all 24-hour safety assessments (electrocardiogram \[ECG\], a brief physical examination, vital signs, and laboratory assessments) an independent Data Safety Monitoring Board/Data Monitoring Committee (DSMB/DMC) determined whether the remaining 6 subjects were to be dosed.

Pharmacokinetic blood samples were obtained prior to dosing and at specified intervals during the study (0-72 hours post-dose). Blood draws for laboratory testing were performed prior to dosing and at 24 hours post dose. After safety assessments of ECG, vital signs, and a brief physical exam at 72 hours, subjects were discharged from the clinic and returned 7 days post-dose for a final safety assessment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Maximum Plasma Concentration (Cmax)
outcomeMeasures.description: The peak drug concentration will be obtained directly from the data without interpolation.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Separate dose cohorts of 6 active and 2 placebo received 50, 100, or 200 mg. A sentinel dose group of 1 active and 1 placebo preceded each full dose cohort.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Blood samples will be drawn on Day 1 after dosing at 20, 40, and 60 minutes and at 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 24, 36, 48 and 72 hours.

otherEvents.notes: lightheadedness upon standing was resported for a subject in the 100 mg group at 1 h post-dose
One subject in the 200 mg group reported transient musculoskeletal wall pain
The same subject in the 200 mg group who reported transient musculoskeletal wall pain, also reported acne

explanation_target: Reason: The investigational agent in the trial is PTI-125, an oral small molecule that binds an altered conformation of filamin A (FLNA) and restores its native shape to block downstream amyloid-beta–related signaling, reduce tau hyperphosphorylation and neuroinflammation — i.e., a drug intended to modify Alzheimer’s disease pathology rather than only symptomatic cognitive enhancement or psychiatric symptom relief. citeturn0search2turn0search0turn1search0

Act: Key extracted trial details — Title: "A Phase I, Single Center, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Single Ascending Dose, Pharmacokinetic and Safety Study of PTl-125 in Healthy Volunteers." The Phase I study tested single oral doses (e.g., 50, 100, 200 mg) in healthy volunteers and was randomized and placebo-controlled. PTI-125 is the investigational small-molecule therapeutic; it is also referred to commercially by Cassava as simufilam (USAN name reported as sumifilam). These trial specifics and drug IDs are documented in the NCT/trial listing and company publications. citeturn0search4turn1search0turn1search3

Reflect: Classification check — PTI-125/simufilam is a small-molecule, orally administered agent with a defined molecular target (altered filamin A) and preclinical/biomarker data suggesting disease-modifying effects, so it matches the definition of 'disease-targeted small molecule' rather than a biologic, a pure cognitive enhancer, or a neuropsychiatric symptomatic treatment. No major ambiguity in the trial description contradicts this classification. citeturn0search2turn0search0

explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational small molecule PTI-125 (simufilam) preferentially binds an altered conformation of filamin A (FLNA) and restores its native shape to prevent FLNA-mediated aberrant receptor interactions that enable amyloid-β (Aβ) toxic signaling (α7nAChR and TLR4), with downstream effects on tau hyperphosphorylation and neuroinflammation — i.e., the mechanism is intended to block Aβ-related pathogenic signaling rather than only symptomatic relief. citeturn0search2turn0search3

Act: Extracted trial/drug details and mechanistic evidence — PTI-125 (simufilam / sumifilam) is an oral, disease‑targeted small molecule tested in Phase I healthy-volunteer single‑ascending‑dose studies (e.g., 50–200 mg). The compound’s described molecular action is binding altered FLNA and restoring its conformation to block Aβ-triggered toxic signaling; sponsor and trial reports describe the Phase I dosing and safety. citeturn0search5turn0search1turn0search4

Reflect: CADRO mapping — although the direct molecular target is filamin A (a scaffolding/cytoskeletal protein), the intended therapeutic effect is to interrupt amyloid‑β–related pathogenic signaling (and thereby reduce tau pathology and neuroinflammation). Under CADRO, the most specific match is A) Amyloid beta because the intervention is designed to block Aβ-driven signaling pathways that drive core AD pathology rather than primarily targeting inflammation, tau, or general proteostasis alone. I note the agent also affects tau and inflammation downstream, but those are secondary effects of blocking Aβ signaling rather than the primary target class; therefore R) Multi-target is not most appropriate. citeturn0search3turn0search2
